results.title: Cross and passion
results.creator_credit: BFI, Kim Longinotto and Claire Pollak
results.brief_description: The women of Northern Ireland tell their stories in this film shot in the troubled Catholic ghetto area of West Belfast. Shows how life for Women in Belfast’s ghettos is dominated by the contrasting power of the church and army.

results.title: Cronos = La Invencion de Cronos [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Iguana Productions (MX), Arthur H Gorson, Bertha Navarro and Guillermo del Toro
results.brief_description: Guillermo Del Toro’s feature debut takes classic vampire mythology into unusual and unexpected terrain. The Cronos of the film’s title is an ornate and intricate beetle shaped device which houses an ancient slug like insect, which once attached to its host, has similar side effects to vampirism. Designed by a 16th century alchemist, the thought to be lost contraption resurfaces in contemporary Mexico and falls into the hands of antique dealer, Jesus Gris (Federico Luppi). The old man, fascinated by its ornate and mysterious beauty, decides to hold on to it, oblivious to its destructive power. However, he is not the only one aware of the Cronos’ existence and soon finds himself being pursued by a dying millionaire (Claudio Brook) and his violent henchman (Ron Perlman). Del Toro’s screenplay takes a sombre and quirky approach to the themes of death and immortality but at it’s heart rests a touching portrait of Jesus’s relationship with his mostly silent but protective granddaughter, Aurora (Tamara Shanath). In Spanish and English with English subtitles.

results.title: Cromwell
results.creator_credit: Irving Allen, Ken Hughes and Columbia
results.brief_description: The last flourish of the decadent Cavaliers, the obdurate zeal of the insurgent Puritans, the mighty clashes in Parliament and on the battlefields, the king’s death on the headsman’s block - a crucial phase of British history is encompassed in “Cromewell”. This powerful story unfolds majestically against a backdrop of pageant, bloody battle and the agonies of a country torn by civil war. Stars Alec Guinness as Charles I and Richard Harris as Oliver Cromwell with a distinguished supporting cast.

results.title: Crofter boy
results.creator_credit: Thames and Clyde Film Company and Stanley Russell
results.brief_description: The life, education and activities of crofter children against the impressive background of the Scottish highlands. Shows how the coming of electricity to the crofters’ homes, the development of local industries and the mechanisation of agriculture, are gradually changing the traditional pattern of life. Local school-children at Gairloch and Poolwe in Western Ross appear in the film, with Kenneth Mackenzie, a crofter’s son, as the main character. Commentary by James McKechnie.

results.title: Crocodile hunters
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Lee Robinson
results.brief_description: In the rivers and billabongs of Northern Territory the aborigine hunts small fresh-water crocodiles using spear and canoe, to provide food for his family. But, in recent years, a new industry has become established in these regions - the hunting of the crocodile for his skin, which brings a high price in the south when manufactured into hand-bags, shoes, wallets and ornaments. Teams of hunters make their camps by the rivers and estuaries where fresh-water and salt-water varieties are found. Photography by Frank Bagnall.

results.title: Crocodile Dundee: Crocodile Dundee II
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Hoyts, Rimfire Films and John Cornell
results.brief_description: This double set features Australia’s highest grossing comedy film, ‘Crocodile Dundee’, and its significantly less successful sequel. ‘Crocodile Dundee’ (Producer: John Cornell, Director: Peter Faiman) A New York reporter is intrigued by stories of an Australian crocodile hunter and accompanies him on a journey through the bush. She entices him back to Manhattan where his easy-going approach to the dangers of life in a big city make him a success in New York society. ‘Crocodile Dundee II’ (Producers: John Cornell, Jane Scott, Director: John Cornell) begins in New York where Dundee now lives with his journalist girlfriend, who he managed to secure in the first film. In order to escape the pursuit of an international drug ring who have murdered her former husband, Dundee and his girlfriend return to the Australian outback where Dundee is well prepared to confront them. Cast includes Paul Hogan, Linda Kozlowski, John Meillon, Mark Blum and David Gulpilil.

results.title: Criticus
results.brief_description: A satirical look at the eternal triangle of the art world - the artist, the audience and the critic. The arrogance of Criticus, the critic, infuriates both the musician and his audience, and a friend of the performer decides to get rid of the nuisance. However, it is not as easy as he thinks.

results.title: Critical thinking: making sure of facts
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and Dick Larson
results.brief_description: Timely topics dealing with reading, listening and television viewing help demonstrate how to evaluate the facts about a particular situation. This involves knowing whether information is based on an eye-witness or secondary account, checking the sources of information, and assessing the skills and knowledge of the source.

results.title: Critical path in use
results.creator_credit: British Productivity Council and Sam Napier-Bell
results.brief_description: In planning a new undertaking, a chart is made to show each move as a separate step in an integral plan. This technique helps to solve many problems on paper before they occur in practice. Shows the drawing up after discussion of a Critical Path Analysis for work on a major project. The advantages of the system for all units are emphasised, and reference is made to the British export effort.
